Milky Way produces approximately one new: How many stars does the Milky Way produce each year? Milky Way star formation rate

Star formation within the Milky Way currently involves about 4 solar masses of gas condensing into stars each year. Since the average star is less massive than the Sun, astronomers believe the Milky Way is producing roughly 7 stars per year. So far, the Milky Way has converted about 90% of its gas content into stars.

detail.reasoning: The given text states that the Milky Way produces approximately one new star every year. However, the provided evidences suggest otherwise. Multiple sources indicate that the Milky Way produces between six to seven new stars per year. Specifically, one evidence states that the Milky Way is producing roughly 7 stars per year, and another mentions that on average, roughly six to seven new stars form in the Milky Way every year. These evidences contradict the claim in the text that only one new star is formed annually.
detail.error: The text incorrectly states that the Milky Way produces approximately one new star every year.
detail.correction: Milky Way produces approximately six to seven new stars every year.
detail.claim: Milky Way produces approximately one new star every year
